description.narrative: 1.SDG Roadmap to promote implementation of nationalized SDGs 2.Number of indicators for national development plans and SDGs with data sources and means of verification 3.1. Number of SDG accelerators identified 3.2. Number of policy papers/briefs produced 3.3. Number of round tables conducted

comment.narrative: No overarching national sustainable development strategy exists 2. The Government acknowledges the need in formulation and implementation of development policies and programs with particular focus on mainstreaming sustainable development into national development agenda. 3. The Government acknowledges the need for high quality comprehensive sectoral studies to inform the process of formulation and implementation of the structural adjustments strategy and mainstreaming sustainable development into national development agenda 4..No systematic mechanism and capacity to identify, analyse and consolidate best practices and solutions for sustainable development

Coherence between SDGs and national development plans and programs is ensured and gaps minimized • Azerbaijan Dashboard on SDG formulated • Rapid Integrated Assessment for Azerbaijan is conducted • Draft of detailed action plans for mainstreaming and acceleration of SDGs are formulated • Sound policies favouring the country’s needs in structural adjustments and mainstreaming sustainable development into national development agenda formulated • Support to the government and other stakeholders in tailoring nationalized SDGs into national, sub-national and local context provided • SDG accelerators identified through modelling and policy simulation to lead the SDG implementation • Report to the ECOSOC High Level Political Forum prepared • Communication and advocacy strategy developed • Outreach and Communication Products are designed on the basis of Policy Simulation exercise • National online resource (web portal) developed and launched • First SDG National Conference conducted • Local best practices and solutions identified and analysed thru series of lectures/workshops/forums on SD

Coherence between SDGs and national development plans and programs was ensured and gaps minimized • Azerbaijan Dashboard on SDG formulated • Rapid Integrated Assessment for Azerbaijan was conducted • Draft of detailed action plans for mainstreaming and acceleration of SDGs were formulated • Sound policies favouring the country’s needs in structural adjustments and mainstreaming sustainable development into national development agenda formulated • Support to the government and other stakeholders in tailoring nationalized SDGs into national, sub-national and local context provided • SDG accelerators identified through modelling and policy simulation to lead the SDG implementation • Report to the ECOSOC High Level Political Forum prepared and submitted • Communication and advocacy strategy developed • Outreach and Communication Products were designed • National online resource (web portal) developed and launched • Local best practices and solutions identified and analysed thru series of lectures/workshops/forums on SD

description.narrative: Study on gender-specific barriers for economic and social participation of women and girls: Yes/No

comment.narrative: No study on gender-specific barriers for economic and social participation of women and girls

-To conduct the study assessment in Baku and 6 regions of Azerbaijan for collecting evidence materials on the reasons, preventing women and girls from accessing economic and employment opportunities in the private sector both in rural and urban areas. -To produce the report with recommendations to the private sector as well as to the stakeholders based on study assessment findings. -To present the study assessment findings to a wide range of stakeholders for further advocacy and action.

-study assessment in Baku and 6 regions of Azerbaijan for collecting evidence materials on the reasons, preventing women and girls from accessing economic and employment opportunities in the private sector both in rural and urban areas was conducted; - the report with recommendations to the private sector as well as to the stakeholders based on study assessment findings was produced

Support the creation of enabling environment for economic and social activity of rural women.
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Neftchala

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

Indicator 1.1: a)Training Manual for WRC staff developed (yes/no) b)WRC staff trained c)WRC library developed (yes/no) d)WRC Strategy, yearly Action Plan and Events Calendar developed {yes/no} Indicator 1.2.1 Assessment of labour market needs developed (yes/no). Indicator 1.3.2: Number of courses /beneficiaries. Indicator 1.4 Number of women reached by the awareness campaign. Indicator 1.5.1 Number of proposals evaluated indicator 1.5.2 Number of women awarded. Indicator 2.1 a) Training Manual on Strengthening Women's Social Participation in Rural Areas and guidelines on Basics of NGO Establishment and Management developed (yes/no). b} Number of training participants Indicator 2.2; Number of copies distributed. Indicator 3.1 a)Training Manual on gender sensitive service provision developed (yes/no). b)Training conducted (yes/no)
Indicator 3.2 a)Job fair conducted (yes/no) b)Number of potential employers represented at the job fair Indicator 4.1 a} Training Manual developed (yes/no). b) Training conducted (yes/no). Indicator 4.2 a) The Guidelines for Supporting Rural Women booklet developed (yes/no). b) The booklet distributed among SCFWCA staff {yes/no}. Indicator 5.1 Assessment developed (yes/no). Indicator 5.2 Recommendations developed (yes/no).

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1 The pilot area lacks efficient mechanism for providing information and skills necessary for strengthening economic participation of rural women Baseline 1.2 There is a shortage of information regarding employment opportunities and demands of local labour market. Baseline 1.3 Many rural women lack skills required by the local labour market. Baseline 1.4 Low awareness regarding the benefits of women's economic participation among general population. Baseline 1.5. Rural women lack incentives and resources to start-up small businesses Baseline 2.1 Women in the Sabirabad region are not dynamically involved in community based activism and presence of Women NGOs. Baseline 2.2 Low awareness regarding the benefits of women's soda! participation among general population. Baseline 3.1 Currently financial services are not sensitized to the needs of rural women entrepreneurs and local private employers are not aware of the potential of rural women as prospective employees. Baseline 4.1 The SCFWCA's staff requires further capacity development in policy and program development for addressing the needs of rural women. Baseline 5. There is a shortage of information regarding the problems and opportunities shaping local environment for economic empowerment and social participation of rural women in various regions on Azerbaijan.

• Economic mapping of Neftchala and Salyan conducted • At least 3 informative meetings with women of Salyan arranged • 20 women entrepreneurs attend business development workshops in Neftchala • 20 women participate in business plan development workshop in Salyan • Maximum 5 businesses established by women in Salyan • 60 teachers attend gender workshops in Neftchala (40 teachers) and Salyan (20 teachers) • At least 10 events and 1 community project administered by WRC in 2016 • 20 public officials (men and women) attend the training • Educational materials published and distributed • At least 50 men and 50 women attend [at least 3] public meetings organized for women’s empowerment campaign • At least 15 young facilitators trained and actively engaged • Gender awareness sessions conducted in at least 10 schools (1 in centre and 4 village schools of Neftchala and 2 in centre and 3 village schools of Salyan) • Water awareness sessions conducted at least in 5 rural communities

• Economic mapping of Neftchala and Salyan conducted • 3 informative meetings with women of Salyan arranged • 20 women entrepreneurs attend business development workshops in Neftchala • 23 women participate in business plan development workshop in Salyan • 8 businesses established by women in Salyan • 24 teachers attended gender workshops in Neftchala • 6 events administered by WRC in 2016 • More than 800 people attended public meetings organized for women’s empowerment campaign • 15 young facilitators trained and actively engaged • 3 water awareness sessions conducted, reaching 5 rural communities

• 20 public officials attend the workshop on “Gender-sensitive policies and programmatic interventions for economic participation of rural women” • At least 1 community project implemented in Neftchala • 40 women attend business/financial literacy training in Neftchala and Salyan • 4 new businesses started in Neftchala and Salyan • 40 women/girls attend vocational courses in Neftchala • 5 outreach events administered by Neftchala WRC • 15 new young trainers trained and actively engaged • Gender awareness sessions conducted in at least 10 rural schools/communities • New WRC established in Salyan

• 20 public officials attended the workshop on “Gender-sensitive policies” in April 2017 • 6 community projects implemented in Neftchala region • 35 women attended business development training in Neftchala (June 2017) and Salyan (July 2017) • 5 businesses supported in Neftchala and 9 businesses supported in Salyan • 80 women/girls attended vocational courses in Neftchala and Salyan • 5 public events administered by Neftchala WRC in 2017 • 15 new young trainers trained • Gender awareness sessions were conducted in 11 rural schools/communities • New WRC was established in Salyan

20 public officials attend the workshop on “Gender-sensitive policies and programmatic interventions for economic participation of rural women” • At least 1 community project implemented in Neftchala • 40 women attend business/financial literacy training in Neftchala and Salyan • 4 new businesses started in Neftchala and Salyan • 40 women/girls attend vocational courses in Neftchala

• 20 public officials attended the workshop on “Gender-sensitive policies” in April 2017 • 6 community projects implemented in Neftchala region • 35 women attended business development training in Neftchala (June 2017) and Salyan (July 2017) • 5 businesses supported in Neftchala and 9 businesses supported in Salyan

Same as above the main focus in the first year of implementation was to get the project running through addressing basic equipment needs like portable water meter cars and electronic equipment for the team The capacity development indicator will be measured and reported by the midterm review

description.narrative: Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

comment.narrative: gt35

15
Though the Project Document has been signed by the Government in June 30 2014 its implementation has been delayed to the late appointment of the Project Director and then the creation of the Project Team During the first year of implementation main activities were concentrated on the purchase of the very basic required equipment like portable water meter cars and electronic equipment for the team Therefore the financial sustainability of the project remains at the baseline level Positive changes are expected and they will be reported by the midterm evaluation

description.narrative: Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool scorecard GizilAgaj

comment.narrative: gt45

25
For the reasons already stated above management effectiveness of the GizilAgaj PA remains at the baseline level Positive changes are expected and they will be reported by the midterm evaluation

description.narrative: Total annual budget HR OPEX and CAPEX allocation for marine and coastal PAs USha

comment.narrative:
All PAs US303ha
GizilAgaj US 253ha

All PAs gtUS4ha
GizilAgaj gtUS4ha

All PAs US311ha
GizilAgaj US 197ha
At first sight it looks like the total annual allocations for Marine and Coastal Protected areas has increased overall but decreased for GizilAgaj In reality however in AzN terms local currency of Azerbaijan the funding for all marine and costal areas including GizilAgaj area has increased In February 2015 AzN depreciated by 34 against the dollar Therefore if calculated using the exchange rate before AzN depreciation respective numbers for all marine protected areas would be 416ha 311x134416 and for Gizilagaj 264ha 197x134264

description.narrative: Enhanced management effectiveness of the GizilAgaj reserve complex
Average number month during spawning season of illegal sturgeon poaching incidents or violation of fishing permits occurring in GizilAgaj

comment.narrative:
Spring gt8
Autumn gt6

Spring lt2
Autumn lt2

51 cases of illegal sturgeon poaching were registered by an authorised service of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources The reported data however show the total number of illegal incidents for both winter and spring seasons The Project Team will request the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources to provide data disaggregated by seasons for the next reporting period

description.narrative: Average number monthyear of cattle illegally grazing in GizilAgaj

comment.narrative: gt500month
lt10month

653 cases of cattle illegal grazing in GizilAgaj were registered by the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources during the entire year or 54 illegal incidents per month on average Even though the reported monthly average is still significantly high compared to the EoP target of 10 it is already significantly lower than the baseline indicator

description.narrative: Improved collaborative governance of and institutional expertise in the financial management of marine and coastal protected areas
Incomeannum US by source from marine and coastal protected areas

comment.narrative:
Government US480822
Donors US277720
Entry fees US3902
Tourism services US0
Fines US45356
Resource use US0
Concessions US0
baseline year 20112012

Government gtUS750000
Donors gtUS500000
Entry fees gtUS15000
Tourism services gtUS10000
Fines gtUS75000
Resource use gtUS10000
Concessions gtUS10000
target year 201617

According to the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources the reported income by source is as follows
GovernmentUS545523
DonorsUS190000
Entry feesUS 2611
Tourism servicesUS0
FinesUS40833
Resource use US0
Concessions US0
The decrease in the donor funding for the marine protected areas is explained by the fact that donor funding varies between years depending on the particular activities and expenses planned for that particular year In some years there is an increase and in some years some decrease in donor funding depending on particular steps This decrease is not an indicator of diminishing attention to the marine protected areas on the side of donors
In turn the small decrease in the entry fees is explained mainly by the exchange rate change between USD and the local currency The decrease is attributed mainly to the exchange rate change Current 2611 by taking into account 34 local currency devaluation would bring current fees to 3499 AzN slightly below the baseline amount of 3902 Also not forget that the number of tourists also varies between years therefore depending on many trivial reasons like weather during holiday period or something else Still the MENR pays attention to this issue and the last year made necessary changes in the regulation allowing now for visitors to buy entrance tickets directly from the National parks The MENR understands that such a low entrance fee collection is unsatisfactory and takes measures to increase the entrance fee collection by using propaganda and easing access to the sites

description.narrative: Number of MENR staff completing inservice financial training and skills development programmes

comment.narrative: gt10

0
There were no trainings or other capacitybuilding activities conducted during the first year of project implementation The project is on track and respective capacitybuilding activities are planned for the second and third years of project implementation

description.narrative: Number of business plans operational in individual marine and coastal national parks

comment.narrative:
0
Development of business plans is scheduled at later stages of project implementation The reason being that initially the protected area should be provided with currently absent basic equipment capacity building and grown ownership of the projected area As initial surveys are shown reflected in the baseline surveys no business plans are yet for the marine protected areas in Azerbaijan There is no respective expertise in Azerbaijan yet Therefore the project team is in the process of development of the respective ToR to hire an international expert to assist the MENR and the Project Team in the development of business plan There is a positive feeling based on the steps already made that the planned target will be achieved

description.narrative: Number of indicators of ecosystem health being regularly monitored and used to guide decisionmaking in marine and coastal protected areas

0
The resource base of the Protected area has been significantly improved through the purchase of important equipment like portable water meter kits Even though no progress can be reported in this PIR significant advances are expected in the following years of project implementation

The Project inception workshop was held in Baku with participation of many stakeholders Also the project conducted a meeting with the local community in Baligchilar settlement during the reporting period After the meeting with the local community the idea emerged to conduct the meeting also with the schoolchildren and their teachers at the local school This meeting was also held successfully with QA session following the information session with the respective prices for the most knowledgeable students However no new partners emerged yet during first year of implementation It is expected that there will be enhanced participation in the coming years of project implementation

first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: to extend the reach of the Information and Communication Technologies with a view to increase efficiency of the public sector institutions

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: to extend the reach of the Information and Communication Technologies with a view to increase efficiency of the public sector institutions

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: to extend the reach of the Information and Communication Technologies with a view to increase efficiency of the public sector institutions

description.narrative: Accountability - local government finance

1) New ICT strategy developed and enacted (Y/N) 2) Extent to which the existing data transmission network - AzDataCom - is upgraded and expanded 3) Extent to which national capacities to exploit the application of ICTs to engage citizens in e-participation are increased. 4) Data Centre as a facility for secure, environmentally safe data storage exists (Y/N)

comment.narrative: 1) National ICT strategy expired in 2013. 2) 0 3) Capacities are not adequate (=1) 4) 0 (does not exist)

Due to structural changes in the Ministry of Communications & High Technologies the project implementation delayed for the whole 2016. Discuss with Ministry new project activities and develop a Substantive Project revision.
Following the Project Steering Committee meeting a Substantive Project revision was prepared and approved.

1. Monitoring of implementation and follow up of “Concept Note on Introduction of e-Participation” in Azerbaijan is prepared. 2. Handbook/manual on improving access of population to government data is prepared and submitted to government institutions. 3. The “National Concept Note on Knowledge-based and Innovative Economy” is developed. 4. Selected Azerpost offices are equipped with PCs or booths; trainings are delivered to Post Offices’ employees. 5. The 5th Regional Internet Governance Forum is launched.

1. International expert prepared Monitoring Report of the "E-Participation Opportunities Analysis in Azerbaijan". In the scope of the project component in order to improve active usage of e-participation the project have organized workshops in Guba and Ganja on Universal Value Wikipedia: Wiki Management (number of participants over hundred). 2. The. ToR for the international consultant for preparation of the Handbook/manual on improving access of population to Open Government Data is prepared and consultant will be hired in 2018. 3. An international consultant was hired to draft the “National Concept Note on Knowledge-based and Innovative Economy”. The Concept will be reviewed by the Ministry in 2018. 4. The have hired a local expert for preparation of the “Electron Azerbaijan” handbook. Trainings on e-government for local authorities, business and civil societies in the regions of Azerbaijan, Ganja and Guba (number of participants more than hundred) were organized. Selected Azerpost offices will be equipped in 2018. 5. The Regional Internet Governance Forum website was updated and redesigned. The 5th Regional Internet Governance Forum Baku, Azerbaijan (RIGFAZ 2017) under the slogan of “Internet as the key to innovation and prosperity" on 7th December 2017 was organized with participation of more than 150 people from ICT society.

description.narrative: This project is placed within the existing national framework of Azerbaijan and provides a particular focus on a programmatic NAMA approach that reflects specific greenhouse gas mitigation measures
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Energy efficiency in buildings in Garadag and Sumgayit, energy efficiency in transport in Baku, and associated gas capturing in Siyazan

description.narrative: 1) Number of NAMAs in energy end-use sectors implemented 2) Direct and indirect GHG emission reduction and energy savings facilitated by the project 3) Co-financing leveraged for implementation of prioritized NAMAs

comment.narrative: 1) No strategic programme in place that prioritises EE and RE requirements 2) Direct and indirect GHG emission reduction and energy savings facilitated by the project: 0 3) Co-financing leveraged for implementation of prioritized NAMAs: 0

1) Energy Efficient retrofitting were conducted at 5 building, including two administrative and three service buildings; energy audit of those building has been conducted and its results used for project reporting, midterm evaluation and MRV report preparation. 2) Outdoor and Indoor trainings were conducted for 79 SOCAR drivers in EE driving; the simulator for more efficient, safe and convenient trainings in eco-driving is being purchased. 5 EE vehicles were purchased for demonstration purposes and their energy saving potential is being tested and monitored 3) The assessment of gas capturing potential at Siyazan Oil&Gas fields has been conducted in cooperation between local and international consultants. Necessary technical specification and tender documents were prepared. The Project team is in the process of tendering of the necessary equipment.

description.narrative: Better coordination of protection of the land border between Georgia and Azerbaijan
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project upgraded monitoring and surveillance systems of the State Border Service on the border with Georgia.

description.narrative: Defence - policy, planning and administration
Extent to which the capacities for border management and oversight are strengthened.

comment.narrative: Medium extent (=3).

- Baseline assessment of training, equipment, and infrastructural needs of relevant departments is in place and used for developments of the detailed action plan - 12 training and workshop activities to enrich skills and knowledge of Border officials - 114 border guards trained - National IBM concept introduced - Bilateral agreements between two sate regulating cooperation in border management improved - Requested equipment is delivered to partners - Relevant infrastructural assistance is provided

- Baseline assessment of training, equipment, and infrastructural needs of relevant departments carried with assistance from ICMPD - 12 training and workshop activities conducted with assistance from ICMPD and FRONTEX - 114 border guards trained - National IBM concept is drafted and pending final approval by the Government - Bilateral cooperation between two sates in border management improved through development of the draft agreements on operation of border delegates that is expected to be finalized in February 2017 - Requested equipment in total amount of 271,981.09 (USD) is delivered to partners - Tenders for providing o the Relevant infrastructural assistance was posted, activities will be finalized in 2017.
Capacity building activities conducted; Protocol on coordinated patrol of the border between AZE and GEO developed; At least one study tour conducted.

- A total of 5 capacity building activities were implemented within the project in 2017 so far, totally 48 representatives of relevant Azerbaijani border authorities participated in workshops; - 2 study tours to Spain (May 22-25, 2017) and Finland (September 11-14, 2017) were organized to familiarise senior representatives from Azerbaijan and Georgia the work and tasks of border agencies, as well as with Integrated Border Management. The visits focused on facilitation on international cooperation namely border delegates institution. - Additional equipment to the State Border Service have been procured to increase its technical capacities in implementation of regular duties. - Closing conference was organized on September 25, 2017 to present the project outputs and plan future activities.

description.narrative: Support to the development of Red Bridge Border crossing point between Georgia and Azerbaijan

title.narrative: Construction of Fence and Customs Trade Facilitation Operation Unit at Red Bridge Border Crossing Point in Azerbaijan
ITB Construction of Fence and Customs Trade Facilitation Operation Unit at Red Bridge Border Crossing Point in Azerbaijan

description.narrative: Integrated Border Management - to support the Governments of Azerbaijan and Georgia in securing their borders and facilitating the legal passing of persons and goods at the Red Bridge Border Crossing Point (BCP).
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The project aims at supporting Governments of Azerbaijan and Georgia to secure their bodies and facilitate the legal passing of persons and goods at the Red Brodge BCP.

description.narrative: Defence - policy, planning and administration

1) Number of Common capacity building activities carried out; 2) Red Bridge BCP to meet international and EU SPS standards and functional on both sides of the border 3) Awareness on EUMSs best practice on SPS controls at BCPs Systematic SPS trainings for staff 4) SPS facilities and equipment are in place 5) 525 traffic means per day according to the statistical data provided by SCC and RS (year tbc) 6) Fenced off control area constructed according to international standards, Systematic SPS control according to international standards on place 7) SPS facilities and equipment are in place, Systematic SPS control according to international standards on place

comment.narrative: 1) No common capacity building activities in area of SPS 2) SPS checks at Red Bridge are not conducted in full compliance with international and EU regulations 3) Limited awareness on EUMSs best practice on SPS controls at BCPs 4) SPS facilities and equipment outdated or does not exist; ad hoc SPS control 5) No systematic average traffic flow control per day on Red Bridge Check Point 6) No fenced off control area 7) SPS facilities and equipment outdated or does not exist; ad hoc SPS control

- At least 10 common capacity building activities carried out - SPS equipment based on international standards procured, installed and available, - Necessary trainings for SCC and RS staff on SPS and veterinary border controls - At least 10 AZ staff and 10 GE staff participated in Study visits to EU countries - SPS facilities are constructed and equipped; necessary trainings for RS and SCC staff on new equipment conducted - At least 650 traffic means pass the Red Bridge Check point per day by 2018 - Fenced off control area constructed and secured storage/sampling area in place; necessary trainings for SCC on sampling equipment conducted

- Training Needs for Azerbaijan SCC and Georgia Revenue Service assessed. - Number of training programmes for key personnel of Azerbaijan SCC and Georgian RS on General SPS Control Checks at Border Crossing Posts; Phyto-sanitary (Plant Health) Issues, Veterinary (animal health) Issues and Food Safety - records and feedback from training sessions, evaluation and training monitoring reports delivered. - Study Tour to EUMs to demonstrate best practice on SPS controls at BCPs organized. - SPS equipment based on international standards procured and available. - Over 90 customs specialists have attended the trainings organized within the project activity. - Letter of Agreement signed between SCC Academy and UNDP project. - Model Plan of the customs area terminal complex designed.

- At least 10 common capacity building activities carried out - At least 10 AZE staff and 10 GEO staff participated in Study visits to EU countries - At least 650 traffic means pass the Red Bridge Check Point per day by 2018 - Fenced off control area constructed and secured storage/sampling area in place; necessary trainings for SCC on sampling equipment conducted

- Systematic national and bilateral trainings/workshops/seminars for Azerbaijan SCC and Georgian RS personnel on general SPS, veterinary controls and food safety at BCPs carried out; Over 250 customs specialists attended the trainings/workshops organized within the project activity; - Study Tour to Lithuania was organised on 21-28 April, 2017 to get EU best practice on food safety, SPS and veterinary controls at borders. Lithuania State Food and Veterinary Service, Lithuania Customs Service and State Plant Service under the Ministry of Agriculture of Lithuania hosted the Azerbaijan SCC delegation headed by SCC Deputy Chief. 5 high level officials participated at ST to get Lithuanian experience in the field of SPS, veterinary and food safety controls at BCPs. The members of delegation were also informed about new technologies, standards, regulations and working practice on traffic safety of bio materials, plants, food and live animals through national and EU borders. - Appx.620 traffic means pass the RB BCP per day by the end of 2017 - On 18 September, 2017 UNDP announced a bid on “Construction of Fence and Customs Trade Facilitation Operation Unit at Red Bridge BCP” through e-tendering, deadline of which was 20 October. “Shinkar Holding” LLC won the tender and the case was approved by RACP. The contract was signed between UNDP Project and “Shinkar Holding” LLC in total amount of 567 403 USD for TFOU and Fence Construction. The construction works will be completed in 2018.

The project will help the Ministry of Culture and Tourism to strengthen the institutional capacities of the Azerbaijan Tourism and Management University (ATMU).
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: to help the Ministry of Culture and Tourism to strengthen the institutional capacities of the Azerbaijan Tourism and Management University (ATMU)

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration
1) Extent to which the teaching capacities of the ATMU are enhanced to produce qualified personnel for the tourism industry 2) Extent to which regional vocational school is functional

comment.narrative: 1) Partial capacity exists (=2) 2) 0 (school does not function)

1. Enhancing skills and competencies of academic staff of ATMU through international experience (organization of trainings). 2. Establishment of laboratories for Tourism and Hospitality Faculty of ATMU (purchase of necessary equipment). 3. Preparation of Strategic Plan 2016-2024 for ATMU. 4. Support ATMU in obtaining UNWTO TedQual Certification of the faculty of Tourism and Hospitality. 5. Organization of professional trainings for prospective personnel for tourism industry.

1. The Project hired an international consultant to conduct a training course on “Management Consultancy” for the academic staff of the ATMU on December 16-22, 2016. 17 participants (11 women and 6 men) from the Management Department, International Relations Department and Economic Department have attended the training course. 2. After the budget reduction due to the devaluation, after discussions with the Ministry of Culture and Tourism and the ATMU, it was decided to establish only one laboratory in ATMU. The activity will be implemented in 2017. 3. The Project has contracted international and local expert to support ATMU in preparation of the Strategic Plan 2016-2024. During their assignment the consultants recommended to prepare the four-year Strategic Plan instead of eight-year. The issue was discussed with the ATMU Management and it was agreed to prepare the Strategic Plan of the ATMU for 2016-2020. The Recommendations for new Strategic Plan of the ATMU were prepared and the report was handed over to the ATMU. 4. The Project communicated to UNWTO Themis Foundation regarding the UNWTO TedQual Certification of the Faculty of the Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU and received necessary documentation for initiation of the Certification Process. The documents containing the information about current situation of the ATMU were prepared and sent back to the UNWTO Themis Foundation for review. Upon the decision of the Foundation, it was recommended to start UNWTO TedQual Pre-Audit Process. The Agreement between UNDP and UNWTO Themis Foundation was signed in December 2016. The visit of representatives of the Themis Foundation to the ATMU is planned for February 2017. 5. The Project contracted a company to organize 3 months’ trainings for perspective tourism personnel (for guides, receptionists, waiters/bartenders). Besides the specialized subjects, trainings on psychology, ethics, aesthetics, English and Russian Languages were organized. Total number of tra

1. Organization of trainings for ATMU academic staff. 2. Purchase and translation of modern tutorials. 3. Establishment of laboratory for the Faculty of the Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU. 4. Cooperation with UNWTO Themis Foundation on UNWTO TedQual Certification of the Faculty of Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU: • Pre-Audit Process to be conducted by the Consultant of UNWTO Themis Foundation in February 2017. • The UNWTO.TedQual Pre-audit report with the corresponding recommendations for improvement to be provided till May 2017 • Further steps for certification to be determined after the results of pre-audit process 5. Organization of the study tour of the academic and/or managerial staff to the international tourism educational institution.

• The modern tutorials and manuals have been purchased and handed over to the ATMU. • The interactive multimedia application for guides prepared (for the establishment of the laboratory). • Pre-audit of the ATMU conducted by the consultant of the UNWTO. Themis Foundation. The report was handed over to the ATMU • Due to funds transfer delays from the Ministry, the study tour and trainings for ATMU staff will be conducted in 2018.

The overall objective of the action is to increase the role of the civil society in advancing women’s rights and to promote economic and social participation of rural women through civil society organizations.
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: supporting rural women economic empowerment and their participation in the community and social life in the regions

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

Number of NGOs (from among project beneficiaries) reporting making references to training materials Bilasuvar WRC is fully operational WRCs have annual Action Plans developed in participatory manner Number of registered members of WRCs Number of women participating in capacity building workshops and awareness raising session Percentage of women with passing level of improved legal literacy and understanding of training topics Number of women participating in capacity building workshops and awareness raising session Number of women with improved livelihoods due to the project services

comment.narrative: There is a shortage of information on economic opportunities and employer expectations Low awareness about the benefits of women’s social participation among general population and local governance Public agencies and private institutions require practical skills and tools for addressing the needs of rural and female constituencies Unemployment rate disaggregated by sex and age

• 15 NGOs (from among project beneficiaries) reporting making references to training materials • Assessment of the needs and concerns of rural women of Bilasuvar conducted • WRC established and operational in Bilasuvar • WRCs in Bilasuvar, Neftchala and Sabirabad have annual Action Plans developed in participatory manner • At least 50 registered members at each WRC • 300 women participating in capacity building workshops and awareness raising sessions • 70% of women with passing level of improved legal literacy and understanding of training topics • At least 20 women attend the training on Strengthening Women’s Social Participation • Assessment of employment opportunities in local labour market conducted • 130 women participating in capacity building workshops and awareness raising session (incl. 40 women attending trainings on basic professional skills and 40 women attending business development trainings) • 20 women with improved livelihoods due to the project services • Educational materials published and distributed • Regional job fair organized • Total of 10 new women-led businesses are jump-started • 20 representatives (men and women) of private sector institutions attend the relevant trainings

• 15 NGOs leaders and representatives have attended the trainings: Awareness raising session for NGOs to improve their understanding of CEDAW and training to NGOs on effective advocacy to promote women’s rights • Assessment of the needs and concerns of rural women of Bilasuvar conducted in June. The report and recommendations are available and applied in drafting Annual Action Plans for WRC’s • WRC established and operational in Bilasuvar since October 2016 • WRCs in Bilasuvar, Neftchala and Sabirabad have annual Action Plans developed in participatory manner, the outcomes from the Social Participation training, Organizational Development training and 2 assessments were applied in the preparatory stages of the plans • 103 members officially registered in Sabirabad, 169 in Neftchala and over 80 in Bilasuvar • Over 200 women participated in capacity building workshops and awareness raising sessions in 2016 • 56 women attended the training on Strengthening Women’s Social Participation • Assessment of employment opportunities in local labour market conducted was conducted in June, the report and recommendations were presented to the donors and applied in development of the WRC’s plan • Over 150 women attended capacity building workshops, from which 25 attended the training on business development and financial literacy training in 2016 • Educational materials published and distributed on Women Social Participation, Start and Improve your Buisness, NGO Establishment and Management, Organizational Development, education guide on CEDAW convention, effective advocacy, Say no To Violence Against Women • Total of 13 new women-led businesses are jump-started in 2016 • 20 representatives (men and women) of private sector institutions attended the relevant training in Sabirabad

• Assessment of the needs and concerns of rural women and the economic mapping of Masalli conducted • WRC established and operational in Masalli • 20 women attend trainings on basic professional skills • 20 women attend trainings on basics of business development and financial literacy • Total of 5 new women-led businesses are jump-started in • At least 20 women attend the training on Strengthening Women’s Social Participation in Masalli • At least 50 men and women are attend the awareness raising workshops in Masalli • Educational materials published and distributed

• Assessment of the needs and concerns of rural women and the economic mapping of Masalli conducted in June • WRC established and operational in Masalli since June, 73 registered members of active women • The trainings on basic professional skills postponed to 2017 • 27 women attended trainings on basics of business development and financial literacy • Total of 14 new women-led businesses are jump-started in Masalli • 21 women attended the training on Strengthening Women’s Social Participation in Masalli. Annual Action plan developed. • About 80 men and women attended the awareness raising workshops in Masalli • 1000 booklets – Negative Impact of Violence Against Women - were published and distributed during the events Reports and recommendations from the Assessment of needs and concern and employment opportunities were published Training materials were developed on Start and Improve your Business and Financial Literacy, NGO Establishment and Management and Strengthening Women’s Social participation themes

comment.narrative: Launch 12 civil society initiatives aiming to advance the social inclusion, equality and socio-economic rights of the vulnerable groups at the community level benefiting at least 500 persons
• Complete Inception Phase and produce inception report • Establish functioning Project Management Unit • Initiate at least 10 civil society initiatives targeting vulnerable groups
Provide various types of support to 1,000 vulnerable persons through trainings, awareness raising, counseling, provision of legal aid etc

• Capacity needs assessment report produced, development plans formulated • A training on M&E held for CSOs • At least one organisation receiving expert assistance to improve or develop internal organisational policies • At least two thematic trainings organised on issues of human rights and vulnerable groups • At least two networking meetings held

description.narrative: Strengthening national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and building capacity towards implementation of future provisions
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste

Strengthening national decision making towards ratification of the Minamata Convention and building capacity towards implementation of future provisions
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Project implementation office

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: ? 1) No previous Minamata assessment on mercury prepared at national level ? 2) Lack of information on Minamata convention’s provisions and requirements ? 3) Limited preparedness to ratify the convention and implement its provisions

1) Prepare Mercury Inventory for Azerbaijan 2) Prepare Mercury Initial Assessment for Azerbaijan in Azeri 3) Prepare dissemination materials for public-awareness campaign and conduct meetings across the country

1) Mercury Inventory for Azerbaijan has been prepared by using Level 1 Toolkit and when necessary and appropriate Level 2 Toolkit. The team of local consultants worked in close cooperation with the lead international consultant. The results were presented in workshop in Moscow and during the COP meeting in Geneva. 2) Mercury Initial Assessment for Azerbaijan, which included also legal and institutional analysis, social and gender analysis has been prepared and published in Azeri 3) 3 types of dissemination materials were prepared and published: for general public, for policy makers and for specialists. In addition, mercury-free thermometers were purchased and disseminated during public-awareness campaign conducted across the country in schools, clinics, universities, etc.

description.narrative: 1) Number of active Syslab Centers in Azerbaijan 2) Number of newly created Syslab Centers 3) Number of Syslab Centers in the traditionally conservative Southern regions of the country

comment.narrative: 1) No currently actively functioning Syslab Centers in Azerbaijan 2) No Syslab Center in rural area 3) No Syslab Center in the southern region of Azerbaijan

1) Syslab Center in Ganja has been renewed its operations and moved to the new location at Kapaz rayon's Employment Center in Ganja 2) New Syslab Center has been opened in Masally, necessary equipment has been provided and the venue was identified with the help of Masally Executive authorities 3) Newly hired staff for Syslab Center in Masally passed through intensive training by the lead project consultant, also undertake study tour to Ganja and participated in the Project review and planning workshop in December 2016
-Syslab Centre active and operational in Ganja -Syslab Centre active and operational in Masalli -75% of Syslab graduates find employment as the result of participation in Syslab methodology

-Ganja Center trained 5 groups of unemployed youth, with total of 73 youth (68% female participation rate)
-Masalli Center trained 5 groups of unemployed youth, with total of 59 youth (39% female participation rate)
-47 youth (64%) found employment during or immediately after Syslab trainings in Ganja, while 31 youth (53%) found employment during or immediately after Syslab trainings in Masalli. Thus, 59% (78 graduates out of 132) found jobs as the result of participation in Syslab methodology.

title.narrative: Modernizing Vocational Education and Training (VET) Cent

description.narrative: Contribution to the modernisation of the vocational education and training system in Azerbaijan, enhancing quality, equality, relevance and access in line with European standards and practices.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Support to the establishment of Regional Industrial VET competence Centre in Ganja - to improve quality of education for increasing attractiveness of VET in Ganja city and neighbouring regions.
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project aim at the modernization of the VET School in Ganja, development of new curricula and private partnership strategy

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

Indicator 1.1: Regional VET Competence Center is established Indicator 1.2: Skills and employability of the graduates of VET Competence Center are enhanced Indicator 1.3: Partnerships with private sector is established Indicator 1.4: Mechanism for recognition/validation of prior learning (competences) is developed and introduced Indicator 1.5: Awareness on EU best practices in VET is increased

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1: Legal framework is outdated; Equipment does not exist Baseline 1.2: There is no any modern curricula in VET center Baseline 1.3: There is no cooperation of VET system and local business on labour market requirements Baseline 1.4: There is no mechanism for recognition/validation of prior learning
Labour market survey conducted

Target achieved. The study mapped the largest public and private employers in the agricultural and manufacturing sector, identified their and potential human resources needs, and determined specific skills and competences that are deficient at the labour market. The findings of the labour market study will be used for the planning and development of new curricula and modular training courses of the Ganja VET Centre.

description.narrative: Establishment of Regional VET Centre of Excellence in Lankaran Economic Region - to improve quality of education for establishing labour market oriented VET system in Lankaran Economic Region.
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The projet aims at establishing of Regional VET Centre of Excellence in Lankaran Economic Region.

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

Indicator 2.1: Regional VET Centre of Excellence is operationalized and modernized Indicator 2.2: Skills and employability of the graduates of VET Lyceum are enhanced Indicator 2.3: Mechanisms established for partnerships with employers

comment.narrative: Baseline 2.1: No analysis present; Legal framework is outdated; Equipment and building of workshops are worn-out and are not usable Baseline 2.2: There is no any modern curricula in VET centre Baseline 2.3: There is no cooperation of VET system and local business on labour market requirements
Labour market study conducted

Target achieved. The study mapped the largest public and private employers in the agricultural and manufacturing sector, identified their and potential human resources needs, and determined specific skills and competences that are deficient at the labour market. The findings of the labour market study will be used for the planning and development of new curricula and modular training courses of the Jalilabad VET Lyceum.

description.narrative: Enhancing Mine Action Programmee in Azerbaijan - strengthening the Mine Action Programme in Azerbaijan and promotion of the Azerbaijan National Agency for Mine Action as an International Centre for Mine Action.
The project aims to strengthen the Mine Action Programme in Azerbaijan and promote the Azerbaijan National Agency for Mine Action as an International Centre for Mine Action.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The project aims to support the institutional capacity of Azerbaijan National Agency for Mine Action. Project will also look to the possibility and undertake all possible actions required to continue transformation of ANAMA to the International Center for Mine Action.

activity-description.narrative: enhancing capacity of the ABAD regional centre in Balakan and fostering the creation of modern and sustainable family businesses in rural areas

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: enhancing capacity of the ABAD regional centre in Balakan and fostering the creation of modern and sustainable family businesses in rural areas

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

Indicator 1.1: Thirty groups of families from all the regions of the Sheki-Zaqatala Economic Zone are selected and empowered to start their businesses. Indicator 1.2: The number of ABAD staff visited EU countries to learn the European experience in developing family businesses. Indicator 2: An individually tailored pre-production and pre-sale system of family products is developed. Indicator 3: Special brands for family products are created and introduced to the market. Indicator 4: Sale channels of family products are in place.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: No such project, which assists small entrepreneurs throughout the whole business process, has ever been carried out. Baseline 2: Families wishing to start their business lack basic financial and legal knowledge. Baseline 3: Families either lack proper production technology or have outdated ones. Baseline 4: Families either do not have access to business related services or lack financial means for that purpose.
Signing the project document with beneficiary
The project document was signed on 13 December 2017
